prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Olive Green
Description: An art-school student whose ambition is to become an artist. She's just regained consciousness, having been comatose for days after suffering a stab to from the back.
Character 4
Name: Soseki Natsume
Description: A Japanese scholar sent to London to further his research into the English language. He's just been acquitted of a very serious crime.↳A Japanese scholar sent to London to further his research into the English language. He's just been acquitted of a very serious crime, but now finds himself accused of another.
Character 5
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 6
Name: William Shamspeare
Description: The victim of the current case - a failed actor renting a room in the same building as Mr Natsume's lodgings.
Character 7
Name: John Garrideb
Description: A retired army man who's the landlord of the lodgings rented by the defendant, Mr Natsume. An old knee injury means he's confined to a chair most of the time.
Character 8
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 9
Name: Adron B. Metermann
Description: A young man who works for Altamont Gas. He's a witness to the incident.
Character 10
Name: Quinby Altamont
Description: The wife of the owner of the Altamont Gas Company. She's a staunch believer in the superiority of the fuel and utterly unforgiving of gas theft.
Character 11
Name: Duncan Ross
Description: The love of Miss Green's life, who sadly passed away a month ago as a result of gas poisoning.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Secondhand Book Receipt
Description: A receipt for some books that Mr Natsume purchased at a secondhand bookshop. It was submitted as evidence in the trial the other day.
Evidence 2
Name: Nearby Street Map
Description: A street map of the neighbourhood where Mr Natsume has his lodgings. It was submitted as evidence in the trial the other day.
Evidence 3
Name: Pair of Teacups
Description: The teacups used by Mr Shamspeare and Mr Natsume. The one with the green line around the rim was Mr Natsume's. The teacups used by Mr Shamspeare and Mr Natsume. There is no tea ring on the inside of Mr Natsume's cup.
Evidence 4
Name: Torn-Off End of Envelope
Description: A ripped piece of an envelope that was found in Mr Shamspeare's room. The rest of the envelope could not be located. A ripped piece of an envelope that was found in Mr Shamspeare's room. It fits perfectly with an envelope in Miss Green's possession.
Evidence 5
Name: Bar of Soap
Description: A cheap bar of soap that was discovered just outside Mr Shamspeare's window. It's one of two that were found there. A cheap bar of soap that was discovered just outside Mr Shamspeare's window. There is a two centimetre diameter circular depression in the middle of one surface.
Evidence 6
Name: Crime Scene Photograph
Description: A photographic print of the scene taken by police upon their arrival. The victim can be seen unconscious at the table, having been poisoned.
Evidence 7
Name: Victim's Medical Report
Description: A report issued by Scotland Yard's medical officer. It obviously mentions the poison as well as other details gleaned during the police investigation.
Evidence 8
Name: Gas Meter
Description: A meter that dispenses gas for a set time after a coin is inserted. It sports a very strong lock, especially with Mr Shamspeare in mind. A meter that dispenses gas for a set time after a coin is inserted. The attached coin box sports a very strong lock, and there is a tiny hole in its base.
Evidence 9
Name: Handprints on the Wall
Description: Traces of handprints on the wall, discovered using the Skin Print Seeker gun. There are multiple prints on either side of a hanging picture.
Evidence 10
Name: Capital Offender Article
Description: A newspaper article about Selden, a criminal sentenced to receive the death penalty. However, he died of illness in prison whilst his loot remained undiscovered.
Evidence 11
Name: Hidden Photograph
Description: A photographic print found in Mr Shamspeare's room. It shows the landlord, Mr Garrideb, together with a young man.
Evidence 12
Name: Bottle of Poison
Description: A bottle found in the possession of Miss Green with traces of the slow-acting poison strychnine inside.
Evidence 13
Name: Capital Offender's File
Description: Scotland Yard's file about the convicted criminal Selden that includes the newspaper article about him dying of illness in prison.
Evidence 14
Name: Miss Green's Card
Description: A note in an envelope that seems to have been ripped open rather roughly. It contains instructions to meet with someone who claims to have information about Duncan Ross. A note in an envelope that seems to have been ripped open rather roughly. The envelope fits perfectly with a torn-off piece found at the scene of the crime.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: The Japanese man did come to my chamber with tea brew'd in a pot.
Person: Shamspeare
Testimony 1
Testimony: 'Twas in my cup alone that the wicked miscreant secretly pour'd his wicked poison.
Person: Shamspeare
Testimony 2
Testimony: Whilst feigning distraction in our debate, ne'er did a drop of his own drink pass his lips.
Person: Shamspeare
Testimony 3
Testimony: When he departed by and by, I did use the tea that remain'd in his cup to make my coins of ice.
Person: Shamspeare
Testimony 4
Testimony: Thus 'tis no surprise that poison be not found in the tea I did pour into the moulds of soap.
Person: Shamspeare

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's see. I need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. Let me start by looking through the testimonies and cross-referencing them with the evidence.

First, the testimonies are all from Shamspeare. Let's look at them one by one. Testimony 0 says that the Japanese man (probably Natsume) came to his chamber with tea brewed in a pot. Testimony 1 claims that the poison was only in his (Shamspeare's) cup. Testimony 2 says that Natsume didn't drink any of his own tea. Testimony 3 mentions using the remaining tea from Natsume's cup to make ice coins using soap molds. Testimony 4 states that there's no poison in the tea he used for the soap molds, hence why the poison isn't found there.

Now, looking at the evidence. Evidence 3 is the pair of teacups. The description mentions that Natsume's cup (with the green line) has no tea ring inside. A tea ring would indicate that tea was present and maybe drunk. But if Natsume's cup has no tea ring, that suggests he didn't drink from it. However, Shamspeare's testimony 2 says that Natsume didn't drink any of his own tea, which aligns with the no tea ring. But wait, Testimony 3 says that Shamspeare used the remaining tea from Natsume's cup to make the ice coins. If the cup had no tea ring, maybe there wasn't much tea left, but that's not a direct contradiction. 

Evidence 5 is the bar of soap with a circular depression. The soap was found outside the window. The depression might be from making ice coins. Testimony 3 and 4 talk about using the tea from Natsume's cup to make ice coins in soap molds. If the soap has a depression, maybe that's where the ice coins were made. But the problem arises with the presence of poison. If the poison was only in Shamspeare's cup (Testimony 1), then the tea from Natsume's cup (used for the ice coins) shouldn't have poison. However, Evidence 12 is the bottle of poison found in Miss Green's possession. But how does that tie in?

Wait, Testimony 4 says that there's no poison in the tea he used for the soap molds, hence the ice coins wouldn't have poison. But if the poison was in Shamspeare's cup, then the ice coins made from Natsume's cup's tea should be poison-free, which aligns. But maybe the contradiction is elsewhere.

Looking at Evidence 3 again: Natsume's cup has no tea ring. If he didn't drink from it, then the tea in his cup was left. Shamspeare says in Testimony 3 that he used the remaining tea from Natsume's cup to make the ice coins. But if there's no tea ring, maybe the cup wasn't used at all. Wait, the tea ring is caused when liquid is left to dry, leaving a stain. If there's no tea ring in Natsume's cup, that suggests that either the cup was empty or the tea was poured out immediately. But Shamspeare claims he used the remaining tea from Natsume's cup. If the cup had tea left, there should be a ring. But Evidence 3 says there's no tea ring. That's a contradiction. So Testimony 3 (he used the remaining tea from Natsume's cup) would imply there was tea left in the cup, leading to a tea ring. But Evidence 3 states there's none. Therefore, the testimony and evidence contradict each other.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: It was six days ago, at about 5 p.m. I was walking along in the snow when I was suddenly stabbed in the back.
Person: Green
Testimony 1
Testimony: Coincidentally, it happened to be just outside the house where the men in this case have their lodgings.
Person: Green
Testimony 2
Testimony: I was at the tavern on the eve of which thou speak'st, for I had bespoke my supper.
Person: Shamspeare
Testimony 3
Testimony: It was the first time I'd been in the area. I had a little matter to attend to, that's all.
Person: Green
Testimony 4
Testimony: Anyway, I was admitted straight to hospital, so I knew nothing about all of this business.
Person: Green
Testimony 5
Testimony: This note was delivered to me at my address. It's nothing to do with the odd man next to me here.
Person: Green

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's see. I need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. Let me start by going through each testimony and checking against the evidence.

Testimony 3 from Olive Green says: "It was the first time I'd been in the area. I had a little matter to attend to, that's all." So she's claiming she was there for the first time when she was stabbed. Now, looking at the evidences, Evidence 14 is Miss Green's Card, which is a note in an envelope that fits with the torn-off piece found at the crime scene (Evidence 4). The note has instructions to meet someone about Duncan Ross. If Olive Green received this note, it implies she had a reason to be there—specifically, to meet someone regarding Duncan. But her testimony says it's her first time there and she had a little matter, which might be a lie if she was actually there because of the note. That could be a contradiction because the evidence suggests she was there for a specific meeting related to Duncan Ross, not just a random first visit.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: I do remember now. 'Twas a week ago, peradventure, that note was deliver'd unto me.
Person: Shamspeare
Testimony 1
Testimony: On the day writ therein, I did tarry a long hour at The Slug and Salad, yet nobody came.
Person: Shamspeare
Testimony 2
Testimony: Thereafter, on the evening I shared the company of the Japanese fellow, I did see the note had vanish'd.
Person: Shamspeare
Testimony 3
Testimony: I don't know what you mean. You think I snuck into this man's room, do you? Why would I?
Person: Green
Testimony 4

Person: Green

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's try to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other. The user wants only one pair, so I need to check each testimony against the evidence provided.

First, looking at the characters, the main defendant here is Soseki Natsume (Character 4), accused again after being acquitted. The victim is William Shamspeare (Character 6). Olive Green (Character 3) is a key witness since she was comatose but now awake. There's also the torn envelope evidence and the testimonies from Shamspeare and Green.

Testimony 3 is from Olive Green: "I don't know what you mean. You think I snuck into this man's room, do you? Why would I?" She's denying entering Shamspeare's room. But looking at the evidence, Evidence 4 is a torn-off piece of envelope found in Shamspeare's room that matches an envelope in Miss Green's possession (Evidence 14). The fact that the torn piece from the crime scene fits her envelope suggests she was there, which contradicts her denial of sneaking into his room. So the evidence (4 or 14?)... Wait, Evidence 14 is Miss Green's Card, which mentions the envelope fits with the torn piece found at the scene (Evidence 4). So Evidence 4 is the torn piece found in Shamspeare's room, and Evidence 14 is her envelope. But the contradiction would be that the torn piece in Shamspeare's room matches her envelope, implying she was there, which contradicts her Testimony 3 where she denies entering his room. Therefore, Evidence 4 (Torn-Off End of Envelope) contradicts Testimony 3 from Olive Green. So the pair would be evidence 4 and testimony 3.
